revision.text:
{{tone|date=March 2014}} '''Alternative formats''' include [[Sound recording and reproduction|audio]], [[braille]], [[E-text|electronic]] or [[large print]] versions of standard print such as educational material, textbooks, information leaflets, and even people's personal bills and letters. Alternative formats are created to help people who are blind or visual impaired to gain assess to their personal and leisure information either by sight (large print), by ear (audio) or by touch (braille).
== Audio == Audio information is beneficial for many people and can be used by anyone who owns a CD player, a [[DAISY Digital Talking Book|DAISY player]] or a computer. Audio enables people who are blind or visual impaired to access information through hearing, in the sense that print readers would understand it.
=== Choosing audio === Different people are likely to have their own preferences about the way they access audio, depending on their experiences, how comfortable are they with technology, and the equipment they to access the audio content.
=== CD as a medium for accessing information === [[File:Interference-colors.jpg|thumb|Interference-colors]] [[Compact Discs]] (CDs) were first produced in the 1980s to store and playback sound recordings exclusively, and became superior to [[cassette tapes]] (AC) offering better sound and size. Standard CDs have a diameter of 120 millimetres (4.7 in) and can hold up to 80 minutes of uncompressed audio (or 700 Megabytes of data). CDs offer some navigation from the beginning of one track to another, rather than having to fast forward or rewind and guess where the tracks started and finished.[[File:Cassette-tape 8192.jpg|thumb|Cassette-tape 8192]]
Over time, CDs have progressed from being solely for music, to being a format for all kinds of data storage, such as text, images, photos and videos. Educators can use CDs to store educational materials including taped lectures, presentations, and handouts into one compact disc for the student to access on CD players or computers.
== Braille == Braille is a tactile system of raised dots that enables people who are visual impaired or blind to access information by touch. The pattern of raised dots is arranged in cells of up to six dots, creating a total of 63 different combinations possible. Each cell represents an alphabet letter, numeral or punctuation mark. Some frequently used words and letter combinations also have their own single cell patterns.
[[File:A person reading a braille book.jpg|thumb|A person reading a braille book]] Braille can be the building block for language skills and a way to teach spelling, grammar, and punctuations to people with vision loss or who are deaf-blind. Not only do Braille codes represent alphabets, they also denote numbers, symbols, music and mathematical notations, enabling people to learn about different subjects in a different way from most of us. Braille books are available in all subject areas, ranging from modern fiction to mathematics, music and law. As with printed text, Braille makes it possible for people to access information in this format.
== Electronic (e-text) == For many of us, having access to computer equipment and appropriate software makes written information accessible. Today’s technology allows people to do majority of their research online, share documents via email, and download lecture notes from school websites. With written text converted into a format that is readable on the computer, it can be accessed visually with screen magnification software, or through auditory means with text-to-speech technology.
== Large print == Large print is essential for people who have visual or learning difficulties and have trouble reading fine print or deciphering crowded text at one time. Large print usually ranges from 16 to 22 point, while giant print uses fonts that are bigger than 24 point.
Having one single size will not meet everyone’s needs; therefore, it is important to find out which is a comfortable reading size for each individual. Research has demonstrated the positive impacts of providing enlarged font size for people with mild to moderate visual impairments, resulting in an increased reading fluency and speed.
[[Category:Augmentative and alternative communication]] [[Category:Digital libraries]] [[Category:Typography]] [[Category:Books by type]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Use British English|date=January 2018}} Prof '''Andrew Rae Gilchrist''' [[CBE]] [[Royal College of Physicians of Edinburgh|PRCPE]] [[FRSE]] FRCP (1899–1995) was an eminent Scottish cardiologist who served as President of the [[Royal College of Physicians of Edinburgh]] 1957 to 1960. He was their longest serving Fellow: 1929 to 1995 (66 years). He did extensive work on anti-coagulants.<ref>British Cardiology in the 20th century by Mark Silverman & c.</ref> In 1959 he was a co-founder of the [[British Heart Foundation]], a charity raising funds for heart research.<ref name="newulsterbiography">{{cite web|url=http://www.newulsterbiography.co.uk/index.php/home/viewPerson/1776|author=K-Point Internet Solutions - Warrenpoint, Newry, County Down|website=newulsterbiography.co.uk|title=The Dictionary of Ulster Biography|accessdate=18 March 2018}}</ref>
==Life==
He was born on 7 July 1899 the only son of Rev Andrew Gilchrist (1871–1954)<ref name="oup">{{cite web|url=http://oxfordindex.oup.com/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/58545|title=Gilchrist, (Andrew) Rae : Oxford Dictionary of National Biography - oi|website=oxfordindex.oup.com|accessdate=18 March 2018}}</ref> and his wife Catherine Hill. He was born in Holywood, [[County Down]] in [[Northern Ireland]].<ref name="newulsterbiography"/> His parents were Scots and he was sent to [[George Watson's College]] in [[Edinburgh]] for schooling.
At the age of 18 he was conscripted into the [[Royal Field Artillery]] and served for the final year of the [[First World War]]. He graduated from [[Edinburgh University]] in Medicine in 1921. His first job was at [[Addenbrooke's Hospital]] in [[Cambridge]] then he moved to the Princess Elizabeth Hospital for Children before spending a year at the Rockefeller Hospital in [[New York City|New York]]. In 1928 he made the first clinical diagnosis of (and description of) [[Myocardial infarction]] and in 1930 he made the first seven recordings of [[Coronary thrombosis]] in [[Europe]] (published in the Edinburgh Medical Journal). He expressed the opinion that heart attacks were a new disease of the 20th century.<ref name="rcplondon">{{cite web|url=http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/1759|website=munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk|title=Munks Roll Details for Andrew Rae Gilchrist|accessdate=18 March 2018}}</ref>
From 1931 he worked as a Consultant at the [[Edinburgh Royal Infirmary]] alongside Sir [[Stanley Davidson]] and [[Derrick Dunlop]]. He was an examiner in all Scottish universities plus [[Makerere]] University in East Africa and the [[University of Baghdad]]. In 1937 he was elected a Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]]. His proposers were [[Edwin Bramwell]], Sir [[Robert William Philip]], [[Arthur Logan Turner]] and [[Sydney Smith (forensic expert)|Sir Sydney Smith]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Biographical Index of Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783 – 2002|date=July 2006|publisher=The Royal Society of Edinburgh|isbn=0 902 198 84 X|url=https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp1.pdf}}</ref>
In 1961 he was made a Commander of the Order of the British Empire (CBE).<ref>London Gazette 10 June 1961</ref>
In a typically ironic twist of fate he suffered a Myocardial infarction in 1965 forcing hime to retire.<ref>The Times (newspaper) obituary 19 April 1995</ref>
He died on 1 March 1995.
==Family==
In 1931 he married Emily Faulds (died 1967). They had one son (Andrew Kirkwood Rae Gilchrist) and one daughter (Dr. Jennifer Mary Rae Gilchrist). Following Emily's death he married Elspeth Wrightman in 1975.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gilchrist, Andrew Rae}} [[Category:1899 births]] [[Category:1995 deaths]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh]] [[Category:People from Northern Ireland]] [[Category:Scottish surgeons]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Commanders of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:Presidents of the Royal College of Physicians of Edinburgh]]

revision.text:
{{POV|date=June 2016}} [[File:HeavenlyBundlePouch.jpg|thumb|William Sears advises mothers to carry their baby on the body as often as possible.]] '''Attachment parenting''' ('''AP''') is a [[parenting]] philosophy that proposes methods which aim to promote the [[attachment theory|attachment of parent and infant]] not only by maximal parental [[empathy]] and responsiveness but also by continuous bodily closeness and touch.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=2f, 5, 8–10, 110}}</ref> The term ''attachment parenting'' was coined by the American [[pediatrics|pediatrician]] [[William Sears (physician)|William Sears]].
In [[Sociology of the family|family sociology]], attachment parenting is considered to be the most striking manifestation of ''[[Sociology of the family#Intensive mothering and the motherhood mandate|intensive mothering]]'' or ''[[Parental portrayals in the media#New momism|New momism]]''. The doctrine has hence been targeted by criticism from a host of objectors.<ref>See section [[#Controversy|Controversy]].</ref>
==History==
=== Context === Attachment parenting is only one of many responsiveness and love-oriented parenting philosophies that entered the pedagogical mainstream after [[World War II]], and it owes many of its ideas to older teachings, such as [[Benjamin Spock]]'s influential handbook ''[[The Common Sense Book of Baby and Child Care|Baby and Child Care]]'' (1946). Spock had mothers advised to raise their infants according to their own [[common sense]] and with plenty of physical contact – a guideline that radically broke with the preceding doctrines of [[Luther Emmett Holt|L. Emmett Holt]] and [[John B. Watson]]; the book became a bestseller, and Spock's new child rearing concept greatly influenced the upbringing of the post-war generations.
Thirty years later, [[Jean Liedloff]] caused a stir by a "[[continuum concept]]" that she presented to the public in a book of the same title (1975). In [[Venezuela]], Liedhoff had studied [[Ye'kuana people]], and later she recommended to Western mothers to nurse and to wear their infants and to share their bed with them. She argued that infants, speaking in terms of [[evolution]], have not arrived in the [[modernity]] yet, so that today's way of child care – with bottle feeding, use of cribs and baby carriages, etc. – does not meet their needs.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.continuum-concept.org/cc_defined.html |title=Understanding The Continuum Concept | access-date=2015-01-15}}</ref> Later, authors such as Sharon Heller and [[Meredith Small]] contributed further [[ethnopediatrics|ethnopediatric]] insights.<ref>{{cite book |last=Small |first=Meredith F. |title=Our Babies, Ourselves. How Biology and Culture Shape the Way We Parent |location=New York |publisher=Anchor Books |year=1999 }}; {{cite book |last=Heller |first=Sharon |title=The vital touch : how intimate contact with your baby leads to happier, healthier development | location=New York, NY | publisher=Henry Holt | year=1997 }}</ref>
In 1984, [[Developmental psychology|developmental psychologist]] [[Aletha Solter]] published her book ''The Aware Baby'' about a parenting philosophy that advocates attachment, extended breastfeeding and abstinence from punishment, similarly to what William Sears later wrote; however, the point that Solter stressed most was an encouragement of the child's emotional expression in order to heal [[Stress (psychological)|stress]] and [[Psychological trauma|trauma]].<ref>{{cite book |last= Solter |first=Aletha Jauch|title=The Aware Baby |location=Goleta, CA |publisher=Shining Star Press |year=1984 |isbn= }}; {{cite web | url=http://www.awareparenting.com |title=Aware Parenting Institute |access-date=2016-03-10 }}</ref>
In the 1990s, [[T. Berry Brazelton]] invigorated the discussion. He contributed new research about the capacity of even newborn infants to express themselves and their emotions, sensitized parents for these signals, and encouraged them – just like Spock – to follow their own judgment.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/05/01/t-berry-brazelton-memoir/2113683/ |title=At 95, Brazelton shares 'A Life Caring for Children' |access-date=2015-01-16|newspaper=USA Today|date=2013-05-01}}</ref>
=== Origin === William Sears came to the term "attachment parenting" in 1982 by reading Liedloff.<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative parenting : how to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth through adolescence |location=New York |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |year=1983 |edition=pocket book |orig-year=1982}}</ref> Initially, he referred to his new philosophy as "the new continuum concept" and "immersion mothering".<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |edition=pocket book |pages=87, 164, 166, 174, 176, 181ff, 184, 238f}}; {{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=112}}</ref> When he published his book ''Creative Parenting'' in 1982, the concept was largely elaborate already. The "7 Baby-Bs" were not explicitly presented as a [[Canon (basic principle)|canon]] yet, but as basic elements of a new parenting philosophy they were distinctly clear even at that early point.<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |edition=pocket book}}</ref> In 1985, William Sears and his wife Martha Sears began to link the concept – [[ex post]] – with [[attachment theory]] which they had begun to recognize at that time.<ref>Only since 1987 Sears' writings explicitly refer to [[John Bowlby]]'s and [[Mary Ainsworth]]'s writings. {{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Growing together: A parent's guide to baby's first year |location=Franklin Park, IL |publisher=La Leche League International |year=1987}}</ref> From then on, they used the term "attachment parenting".<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Christian Parenting and Child Care |publisher= T. Nelson |location=Nashville |year=1985}}</ref>
{{ Quotation | [...] I realized we needed to change the term to something more positive, so we came up with AP, since the Attachment Theory literature was so well researched and documented, by John Bowlby and others. | Martha Sears<ref>{{cite web | url=http://attachedattheheart.attachmentparenting.org/faq/ |title=How did attachment parenting originate? |access-date=2016-01-20 }}; {{cite book |last1=Nicholson |first1=Barbara |last2=Parker |first2=Lysa |title=Attached at the Heart. Eight Proven Parenting Principles for Raising Connected and Compassionate Children |location=Deerfield Beach, FL |publisher=Health Communications | year=2013 |isbn=978-0-7573-1745-3 |pages=27 }}</ref> }}
In 1993, William Sears and Martha Sears published ''The Baby Book'' which became the first comprehensive manual for AP-parents and which was occasionally dubbed "the attachment parenting bible".<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=William |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The baby book : everything you need to know about your baby : from birth to age two |location=Boston |publisher=Little, Brown |year=1993 }} {{cite web |url=http://www.allparenting.com/my-life/articles/971001/what-attachment-parenting-really-means |title=What attachment parenting really means |access-date=2016-03-15 }}; {{cite web |url=http://www.healthfamilydeals.com/children/babies-pooping-over-garbage-cans-and-hypnotized-toddlers-a-guide-to-progressive-parenting.html |title=Babies Pooping Over Garbage Cans and Hypnotized Toddlers: A Guide to Progressive Parenting |access-date=2016-03-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160325155332/http://www.healthfamilydeals.com/children/babies-pooping-over-garbage-cans-and-hypnotized-toddlers-a-guide-to-progressive-parenting.html |archive-date=2016-03-25 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> The first attachment parenting organization, ''Attachment Parenting International'', formed in 1994 in [[Alpharetta, Georgia]] and was founded by Lysa Parker and Barbara Nicholson.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.attachmentparenting.ca/articles/APAttachmentparenting101.pdf |last=Arnall |first=Judy |title=Attachment Parenting 101 |access-date=2016-03-09 }}; {{cite web | url=http://attachedattheheart.attachmentparenting.org/about-the-authors/ |title=Barbara Nicholson, Lysa Parker |access-date=2016-03-09 }}</ref> The first book that carried the term ''attachment parenting'' in the title was written by Tammy Frissell-Deppe, a mother who gave an account of her personal experiences and of those of her friends and acquaintances.<ref>{{cite book |last=Frissell-Deppe |first=Tammy |title=Every Parent's Guide to Attachment Parenting: Getting back to basic instincts! |location=Dracut, MA |publisher=J.E.D. Publishing |year=1998 |isbn=0-9666341-4-4 }}</ref> In 1999, blogger Katie Allison Granju followed with another book,<ref>{{cite book |last1=Granju |first1=Katie Allison |last2=Kennedy |first2=Betsy |title=Attachment Parenting: Instinctive Care for Your Baby and Young Child |location= |publisher=Pocket Books |year=1999 |isbn=0-671-02762-X }}</ref> to which William Sears contributed a [[foreword]], before he, together with Martha Sears, published his own work, ''The Attachment Parenting Book'' in 2001. All three books stood – with their opposition against a crude behavioristic infant anthropology – in the tradition of Spock, but radicalized the concept of a contingency-oriented parenting on the one hand, and incorporated Liedloff's idea of an instinct-guided resp. "[[Nature|natural]]" childrearing on the other hand.
In the same year as Sears and Sears' ''Attachment Parenting Book'', [[Jan Hunt]] published her essay collection ''The Natural Child. Parenting from the Heart''. Hunt who sees herself as a [[Child advocacy|child advocate]], campaigned in this book not only for attachment parenting, but also for [[unschooling]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.naturalchild.org/ |title=The Natural Child Project}}</ref> A more recent AP proponent is parenting advisor Naomi Aldort, who published her book ''Raising Our Children, Raising Ourselves'' in 2006.<ref>{{cite book |last=Aldort |first=Naomi |title=Raising Our Children, Raising Ourselves: Transforming parent-child relationships from reaction and struggle to freedom, power and joy |location=Borthell, WA |publisher=Book Publishers Network |isbn=978-1887542326 |year=2006 }} {{cite web |url=http://www.naomialdort.com |title=Naomi Aldort's web site |access-date=2016-03-23}}</ref>
==In practice==
=== Babyreading === Like before him the founders of [[attachment theory]], [[Mary Ainsworth]] in particular, William Sears teaches that a strong mother-child-attachment emerges from contingency, that is of emotional attunement of mother and child, which again is based on the mother's [[Sensitivity (human)|sensitivity]]. Since the mother "reads" the signals of her infant, Sears speaks in this context of "babyreading".<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=5–9}}</ref> Another metaphor that he uses is "to be in the groove".<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=18}}</ref>
=== The 7 Baby Bs === William Sears strongly believes in the existence of child rearing practices that support "babyreading" and that augment the maternal sensitivity.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=5, 7}}</ref> The methods of attachment parenting include seven practices resp. principles that according to Sears form a "synergetic" ensemble and that are based on the child's "biological needs".<ref name="Little, Brown and Company">{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=27 }}</ref> Sears refers to those principles as "7 Baby Bs":<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=5f, 11 }}</ref> *Birth bonding *Breastfeeding *Baby wearing *Bedding close to baby *Belief in the language value of your baby's cry *Beware of baby trainers *Balance
Until 1999, Sears named only five Baby Bs. The last two were only added in 2001 with the publication of the ''Attachment Parenting Book''.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Granju |first1=Katie Allison |last2=Kennedy |first2=Betsy |title=Attachment Parenting: Instinctive Care for Your Baby and Young Child |location=New York, NY |publisher=Pocket Books |year=1999 |isbn=0-671-02762-X |pages=xix }}</ref>
==== Birth bonding ==== [[File:Postpartum baby2.jpg|thumb|Mother with newborn]] William Sears postulates the existence of a brief time slot immediately after birth during which the newborn is in a "quiet alert state" and particularly accessible for [[Human bonding|bonding]]. He refers to this birth bonding as "[[imprinting (psychology)|imprinting]]" and bases himself on a study by Marshall Klaus and John Kennell from 1967; however, Klaus and Kennell later modified their original assumptions, including the one cited by Sears.<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |pages=47ff, 52, 54, 183}}; {{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=36–47 }}; {{cite book |last1=Klaus |first1=Marshall H. |last2=Kennell |first2=John H. |title=Maternal-Infant Bonding: The Impact of Early Separation or Loss on Family Development |location=St. Louis |publisher=C.V. Mosby |year=1976}} Sears names the wrong book title; {{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/22/health/john-kennell-advocate-of-infant-bonding-dies-at-91.html?_r=0 |title=John Kennell, Advocate of Infant Bonding, Dies at 91 | newspaper=The New York Times |date=2013-09-21 |access-date=2016-01-15 }}</ref> Sears advises women to abstain from [[analgesic]]s during childbirth, since those drug the child, too, and according to Sears interfere with the birth bonding.<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |p=51}}; {{cite book |last1=Granju |first1=Katie Allison |last2=Kennedy |first2=Betsy |title=Attachment Parenting: Instinctive Care for Your Baby and Young Child |location=New York, NY |publisher=Pocket Books |year=1999 |isbn=0-671-02762-X |pages=58 }}</ref>
==== Breastfeeding ==== William Sears argues that [[breastfeeding]] greatly accommodates mother-child-attachment because it triggers the release of [[oxytocin]] in the mother which supports her emotional bonding with the child, notably in the first ten days after childbirth.<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |p=96, 188 }}; {{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=53–56 }}</ref> In opposition to bottle feeding which tends to being done in 3 to 4 hour intervals, breastfeeding enables the mother, too, to perceive the child's moods and needs exactly.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=56–58 }}</ref> Since the [[half-life]] period of the hormones [[prolactin]] and oxytocin (which promote bonding) are very short, Sears recommends to breastfeed very frequently, newborns in particular (8 to 12 times a day).<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=55f, 60, 120f }}</ref> He claims that the hours between 1 and 6 am are the most beneficial for breastfeeding.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=57 }}</ref> In general, Sears argues that breastfeeding is beneficial for the health of both child and mother.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=54f }}</ref> He claims that infants up to 6 months should be exclusively fed with [[breast milk]], since he believes that, at that age, children are [[Food allergy|allergic]] to all other foods.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=142 }}</ref>
William and Martha Sears advise mothers to breastfeed every child for 1–4 years:<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |p=120 }}; {{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=64 }}; {{cite book |last1=Granju |first1=Katie Allison |last2=Kennedy |first2=Betsy |title=Attachment Parenting: Instinctive Care for Your Baby and Young Child |location=New York, NY |publisher=Pocket Books |year=1999 |isbn=0-671-02762-X |pages=290ff }}</ref>
{{ Quotation | While breastfeeding for only a few months is the cultural norm for Western Society, what we know about breastfeeding in primitive cultures and weaning times for other mammals that human infants were designed to breastfeed for several years. |Bill Sears, Martha Sears<ref name="apb_ix">{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=62 }}</ref> }}
William Sears advocates extended breastfeeding, since he is convinced that breastfeeding supports attachment even of older children and that it is a valid instrument to comfort older children or to bring mother and child together on turbulent days.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=62f }}</ref> Neither does he object nighttime breastfeeding of toddlers.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=99 }}</ref> As early as in 1992, Norma Jane Bumgarner had campaigned for extended breastfeeding.<ref>{{cite book |last=Bumgarner |first=Norma Jane |title=Mothering your nursing toddler |location=Franklin Park, Illinois |publisher=La Leche League International |year=1992 |isbn= }}</ref>
Sears’ recommendations are in accordance with the [[World Health Organization|WHO]] guidelines on breastfeeding, which recommend exclusive breastfeeding in the first 6 months and complementary breastfeeding in the first 2 years for all countries.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.who.int/topics/breastfeeding/en/ |title=WHO: Breastfeeding |access-date=2016-02-22 }}</ref>
Since breastfeeding studies are, for ethical reasons, never conducted as [[randomized controlled trial]]s, critics have repeatedly suspected that studies may have produced the superiority of breastfeeding as an [[artifact (error)|artifact]]. Both the physical, emotional and mental development of children and the preferences of women for a feeding method are strongly determined by [[socioeconomics|socioeconomical]] factors such as the mother's [[ethnic group|ethnicity]], [[social class]], and [[education]]. If researchers go without [[randomization]] and turn a blind eye to those possible alternative factors, they fundamentally run a risk to falsely credit the feeding method for effects of socioeconomical factors.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.sciencebasedmedicine.org/are-the-benefits-of-breastfeeding-oversold/ |title=Are the benefits of breastfeeding oversold? |access-date=2015-02-15 }}; {{cite web | url=http://jhppl.dukejournals.org/content/32/4/595.full.pdf+html |title=Is Breast Really Best? Risk and Total Motherhood in the National Breastfeeding Awareness Campaign |access-date=2015-02-15 }}</ref> A loophole from this problem was first presented by Cynthia G. Colen ([[Ohio State University]]), who successfully factored out socioeconomical determinants by comparing siblings only; her study demonstrated that formula fed children showed only minimal differences to their breastfed siblings, insofar as their physical, emotional and mental thriving was concerned.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Colen |first1=Cynthia G. |last2=Ramey |first2=David M. |title=Is breast truly best? Estimating the effects of breastfeeding on long-term child health and wellbeing in the United States using sibling comparisons |journal=Social Science & Medicine |year=2014 |doi=10.1016/j.socscimed.2014.01.027 |volume=109 |pages=55–65|pmc=4077166 }}</ref>
William Sears' assumptions about the benefit of breastfeeding for the attachment have been studied. In 2006, John R. Britton and a research team ([[Kaiser Permanente]]) found that highly sensitive mothers are more likely than less sensitive mothers to breastfeed and to breastfeed over a long time period. However, the study showed no effect of the feeding method on the attachment quality.<ref>{{citation|last1=Britton |first1=John R. |last2=Britton |first2=Helen L. |last3=Gronwaldt |first3=Virginia |title=Breastfeeding, Sensitivity, and Attachment |journal=Pediatrics |volume=118 |issue=5 |year=November 2006 |url=http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/118/5/e1436?sso=1&sso_redirect_count=1&nfstatus=401&nftoken=00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000&nfstatusdescription=ERROR%3a+No+local+token }}</ref>
==== Babywearing ==== [[File:Position reclining cradle.jpg|thumb|A child in a sling]] Sears advises mothers to wear infants on the body as many hours during the day as possible, for example in a [[baby sling|sling]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=65 }}; {{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |p=78 }}</ref> He argues that this practice makes the child happy and allows the mother to involve the child into everything she does and never to lose sight of the child.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=65, 67f, 70–78 }}</ref> He advises working mothers to wear the child at least 4–5 hours every night in order to make good for her absence during the day.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=133, 139f }}</ref>
In 1990, a research team from New York revealed in a randomized study that children of lower class mothers who to the age of 13 months spent a lot of time in a child carrier on their mother's body showed significantly more frequently a secure attachment as defined by Ainsworth than the control group children, who spend more time in an infant seat.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Anisfeld |first=E. |last2=Casper |first2=V. |last3=Nozyce |first3=M. |last4=Cunningham |first4=N. |title=Does infant carrying promote attachment? An experimental study of the effects of increased physical contact on the development of attachment | journal=Child Development |year=1990 |volume=61 |issue= 5|pages=1617–1627 |pmid=2245751 |doi=10.2307/1130769}}</ref> For middle-class families, an equivalent study doesn't exist yet.
Sears argues furthermore that babywearing exercises the child's [[Equilibrioception|sense of balance]]; since a child who is worn on the mother's experiences more of her conversations, he believes that babywearing is also beneficial for the child's [[language acquisition]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=71f }}</ref> However, there are not studies that confirm such effects.
It is undisputed that babywearing can calm children down. Infants cry the most in the age of 6 weeks; in 1986, a research team at [[McGill University]] showed in a randomized study that infants of that age cried significantly less if their parents wore them a lot on the body during the day.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Hunziker |first1=U.A. |last2=Barr |first2=R.G. |title=Increased carrying reduces infant crying: a randomized controlled trial | journal=Pediatrics |volume= 77|issue=5 |year=May 1986 |pages=641–648 |pmid=3517799 }}</ref> Sears recommends babywearing for the purpose of settling a baby to sleep, too.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=78 }}</ref> He approves on the use of a sling up to the age of 3, since childwearing can also be used to calm a misbehaving toddler down.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=69 }}</ref> Other pediatricians find it disputable to wear children beyond the age of 9 months permanently on the body, arguing that this is against the child's natural desire for autonomy.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://diepresse.com/home/bildung/erziehung/759158/Die-fix-gebundenen-Kinder |title=Die fix gebundenen Kinder |access-date=2015-01-27}}</ref>
==== Co-Sleeping ==== [[File:Christian Krohg - Mother and Child - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|[[Christian Krohg]]: ''Mother and Child'', 1883]] William Sears states that any sleeping arrangement that a family practices is acceptable as long as it works; but he advises mother to sleep close to the child.<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |p=78, 173}}; {{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=91 }}</ref> He thinks of [[co-sleeping]] as the ideal arrangement and refers to it as the nighttime equivalent of babywearing: co-sleeping supports, in his opinion, the mother-child-attachment, makes breastfeeding more convenient, and prevents not only [[anxiety|separation anxiety]], but [[Sudden infant death syndrome|SIDS]], too.<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |p=173}}; {{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=90, 92–95, 102 }}</ref> Sears is convinced that mother and child, in spite of frequent nighttime breastfeeding, have the best sleep when they sleep close together.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=92–94 }}</ref> He is also convinced that due to the extra nighttime feedings, a child that sleeps close to the mother thrives better than a child "crying, alone, behind bars".<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=93f }}</ref> Moreover, Katie Allison Granju argued that co-sleeping is beneficial for children, too, because it gives children a vivid notion of the concept of bedtime.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Granju |first1=Katie Allison |last2=Kennedy |first2=Betsy |title=Attachment Parenting: Instinctive Care for Your Baby and Young Child |location=New York, NY |publisher=Pocket Books |year=1999 |isbn=0-671-02762-X |pages=188f }}</ref>
The idea of co-sleeping was not new in modern Western societies; as early as in 1976, Tine Thevenin had campaigned for the "family bed".<ref>{{cite book |last=Thevenin |first=Tine |title=The Family Bed | orig-year=1976 | year=1987 |publisher=Avery Pub. Group |location=Wayne, NJ }}</ref> Sears doesn't see a problem when a 3 year old still shares his mother's bed every night.<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |p=174}}; {{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=95, 97 }}</ref> He doesn't even object if a child is in the habit of literally spending the whole night with her mother's nipple in her mouth, except when the mother really feels uncomfortable.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=110 }}</ref> Sears advises working mothers to co-sleep on all accounts in order to compensate the child for her daytime absence.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=133, 139 }}</ref>
Sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) is a very rare incident; it occurs in less than ½ per mill of all infants. James J. McKenna ([[University of Notre Dame]]) has discovered that co-sleeping mothers and infants not only synchronize their [[circadian rhythm|sleep-wake-rhythm]], but their breathing, too; he therefore reasons that co-sleeping lowers the SIDS risk.<ref>{{cite journal |last=McKenna |first=James J. |title=Sleep and arousal patterns of co-sleeping human mother/infant pairs: A preliminary physiological study with implications for the study of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) | journal=American Journal of Physical Anthropology |volume=83 |issue=3|year=1990 |pages=331–347 |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ajpa.1330830307/abstract |doi=10.1002/ajpa.1330830307 |pmid=2252080}}</ref> Nonetheless, studies that investigate SIDS ''directly'' have shown that permanent bed sharing rather raises the SIDS risk than lowering it; it is worth noting that in the study, the increased risk of SIDS occurred in infants younger than four months when the parents were especially tired, had consumed alcohol, were smokers, slept on a sofa, or the baby was in a duvet. Otherwise, no increased risk was associated with bed sharing. <ref>{{cite journal |last=Blair |first=P.S. |title=Babies sleeping with parents: case-control study of factors influencing the risk of the sudden infant death syndrome : Cot death—the story so far | journal=British Medical Journal |volume=319 |issue=7223 |year=1999 |pages=1457–1462 |url=http://www.bmj.com/content/319/7223/1457.short |doi=10.1136/bmj.319.7223.1457}}</ref> The U.S. [[Consumer Product Safety Commission]] also warns against co-sleeping.<ref>[http://www.cpsc.gov/CPSCPUB/PREREL/PRHTML99/99175.html CPSC Warns Against Placing Babies in Adult Beds; Study finds 64 deaths each year from suffocation and strangulation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060618130458/http://www.cpsc.gov/CPSCPUB/PREREL/PRHTML99/99175.html |date=2006-06-18 }}, Consumer Product Safety Commission, September 29, 1999</ref> Attachment Parenting International issued a response which stated that the data referenced in the Consumer Product Safety Commission statement were unreliable, and that co-sponsors of the campaign had created a conflict of interest.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.attachmentparenting.org/support/articles/cosleepcritique.php |title=Attachment parenting international calls on government to delay campaign warning parents not to sleep with their babies |accessdate=2014-01-14 |publisher=Attachment Parenting International |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130807102537/http://www.attachmentparenting.org/support/articles/cosleepcritique.php |archivedate = 2013-08-07}}</ref> The American Academy of Pediatrics' policy on SIDS prevention opposes bed-sharing with infants, although room-sharing is encouraged.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1542/peds.106.3.e41 |title=Unsafe Sleep Practices and an Analysis of Bedsharing Among Infants Dying Suddenly and Unexpectedly: Results of a Four-Year, Population-Based, Death-Scene Investigation Study of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome and Related Deaths |year=2000 |first1=James S. |last1=Kemp |first2=Benjamin |last2=Unger |first3=Davida |last3=Wilkins |first4=Rose M. |last4=Psara |first5=Terrance L. |last5=Ledbetter |first6=Michael A. |last6=Graham |first7=Mary |last7=Case |first8=Bradley T. |last8=Thach |journal=Pediatrics |volume=106 |issue=3 |pages=e41 |pmid=10969125}}</ref>
In general, research doesn't confirm an advantage of co-sleeping over separate beds. A [[meta analysis|meta study]] from [[Israel]] has pointed out in 2000 that sleeping aids such as [[pacifier]]s and [[teddy bear]]s significantly improve the child's sleep, while co-sleeping and frequent nighttime breastfeeding if anything hinder the formation of wholesome sleeping patterns.<ref name="ib">{{cite journal |last=Benhamou |first=Isabelle |title=Sleep Disorders of Early Childhood: A Review | journal=Israel Journal of Psychiatry and Related Sciences |year=2000 |volume=37 |issue=3 |pages=190–196 |url=http://search.proquest.com/openview/ff244386c43b4c861a8b94b6b94f2165/1?pq-origsite=gscholar }}</ref> Co-sleeping mothers breastfeed 3 times as frequently during the night as mothers who have their bed for themselves.<ref>{{cite journal |last=McKenna |first=James |title=Experimental studies of infant-parent co-sleeping: mutual physiological and behavioral influences and their relevance to SIDS (sudden infant death syndrome) |journal=Early Human Development |year=1994 |volume=38 |issue=3 |pages=187–201 |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0378378294902119 |doi=10.1016/0378-3782(94)90211-9|pmid=7821263 }}</ref> Most important factor for a good sleep of the child proved to be the mother's emotional accessibility, not her permanent physical closeness.<ref name="ib"/>
==== "Crying is an attachment tool" ==== [[File:Human-Male-White-Newborn-Baby-Crying.jpg|thumb|Crying newborn]] William Sears determines [[crying]] as the child's pivotal mean of self-expression.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=81 }}</ref> Parents are challenged to "read" the crying – which is initially generalized – and to provide the child with empathic feedback in order help him to differentiate and elaborate the repertoire of his signals gradually.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=81f }}</ref> Furthermore, he recommends ''prevention'' of crying: parents are advised not only to practice breastfeeding, babywearing and co-sleeping as much as possible, but also to get into the habit of properly responding to the early warning signals so that crying doesn't happen in the first place.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=82f }}</ref> Likewise, parents must teach their child that some trivial occasions are no cause for alarm at all.<ref>Sears names the method of playing bagatelles down the "Caribbean approach"; {{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=83f, 88 }}</ref>
In general, Sears argues that infants should never been left crying because this would harm them.<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |p=165, 169}}; {{cite web | url=http://www.askdrsears.com/topics/health-concerns/fussy-baby/why-do-babies-cry |title=Why do babies cry |access-date=2015-01-29}}</ref> But as early as in 1962, [[T. Berry Brazelton]] had shown in a study that a certain amount of crying in young infants does not indicate emotional or physical problems, but is to be considered normal and harmless.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Brazelton |first=T. Berry|title=Crying in Infancy |journal=Pediatrics |year=April 1962 |volume=29|issue=4|url=http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/29/4/579?variant=short&sso=1&sso_redirect_count=2&nfstatus=401&nftoken=00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000&nfstatusdescription=ERROR%3A%20No%20local%20token&nfstatus=401&nftoken=00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000&nfstatusdescription=ERROR%3a+No+local+token }}</ref>
==== No sleep training ==== William Sears names two reasons why infants should not undergo [[infant sleep training|sleep training]]: he believes that infant training hardens the mother emotionally and that children who underwent such training don't sleep better but merely resign and become [[apathy|apathic]], a state that he refers to as "shutdown syndrome", although a condition of this name doesn't exist in [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders|DSM]] or [[International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems|ICD]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=121ff, 126f }}</ref> Frissell-Deppe and Granju believe that sleep training is [[Psychological trauma|traumatic]] for children.<ref>{{cite book |last=Frissell-Deppe |first=Tammy |title=Every Parent's Guide to Attachment Parenting: Getting back to basic instincts! |location=Dracut, MA |publisher=J.E.D. Publishing |year=1998 |isbn=0-9666341-4-4 |pages=51 }}; {{cite book |last1=Granju |first1=Katie Allison |last2=Kennedy |first2=Betsy |title=Attachment Parenting: Instinctive Care for Your Baby and Young Child |location=New York, NY |publisher=Pocket Books |year=1999 |isbn=0-671-02762-X |pages=214 }}</ref>
Sears argues that advocates of sleep training are professionally incompetent and merely business oriented, and that there is no scientific proof that sleep training is beneficial for children.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=120, 124 }}</ref>
==== Balance ==== For parents and particularly for mothers, attachment parenting is more strenuous and demanding than most other present-day ways of parenting, placing high responsibility on them without allowing for a support network of helpful friends or family. William Sears is fully aware of the arduousness of the methods.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=107 }}; compare {{cite book |last=Frissell-Deppe |first=Tammy|title=Every Parent's Guide to Attachment Parenting: Getting back to basic instincts! |location=Dracut, MA |publisher=J.E.D. Publishing |year=1998 |isbn=0-9666341-4-4 |pages=introduction }}</ref> He suggests a whole package of measures that aim to prevent an emotional [[occupational burnout|burnout]] of the mother, like the prioritization and delegation of duties and responsibilities, streamlining of daily routines, and collaboration between both parents.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=107–110, 112–117, 143ff }}</ref> Sears advises mothers to turn to a [[psychotherapy|psychotherapist]] if necessary, but to stick to attachment parenting at all costs.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=109, 117f }}</ref>
Sears finds the burden of attachment parenting just and reasonable, and describes the opponents of this philosophy as ''"autoritarian males […] caught up in their role of advice giver"''.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=120 }}</ref> Granju, too, takes a swipe at ''"the male dominated ′scientific′ childcare guidance"''. She argues that the low reputation that breastfeeding, namely extended breastfeeding in the Western world has, arises from a [[sexualization]] of the female [[breast]]: from the perspective of a [[sexism|sexistic]] society, the breast "belongs" to men, not to children.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Granju |first1=Katie Allison |last2=Kennedy |first2=Betsy |title=Attachment Parenting: Instinctive Care for Your Baby and Young Child |location=New York, NY |publisher=Pocket Books |year=1999 |isbn=0-671-02762-X |pages=268, 304 }}</ref> [[Mayim Bialik]], too, considers attachment a [[feminism|feminist]] option, since it constitutes an alternative to the – male dominated – superiority of physicians who traditionally shaped the spheres of [[pregnancy]], [[childbirth]], and [[mother]]hood.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/roomfordebate/2012/04/30/motherhood-vs-feminism/attachment-parenting-is-feminism |title=Attachment Parenting Is Feminism |newspaper=The New York Times|date=2012-05-01|access-date=2015-01-20}}</ref>
Since attachment parenting poses a considerable challenge to the reconcilability of motherhood and [[Women in the workforce|female career]], the philosophy has been greatly criticized, most notably in the context of the [[#Controversy|attachment parenting controversy]] from 2012.
=== Parental authority === Sears states that in attachment families, parents and children practice a highly developed and sophisticated type of communication that makes it unnecessary for parents to use practices such as scolding; often, all it takes is a mere frown. He is convinced that children who trust their parents are cooperative and don't resist parental guidance.<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |pages=215, 236ff}}; {{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=152 }}; {{cite web | url=http://www.askdrsears.com/topics/parenting/discipline-behavior/attachment-parenting-discipline |title=10 Ways Attachment Parenting Discipline is Easier |access-date=2015-01-29}}</ref> He therefore recommends [[positive discipline]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=2 }}</ref> But in contrast to many AP parents, he isn’t fundamentally opposed to confrontative methods (''firm, corrective response''), and he gives high significance to child [[obedience (human behavior)|obedience]] and [[conscience]].<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.askdrsears.com/topics/parenting/discipline-behavior/discipline-for-children |title=Healthy discipline for children |access-date=2015-01-29}}; {{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=William |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Discipline Book: Everything You Need to Know to Have a Better-Behaved Child From Birth to Age Ten |year=1995 }}; {{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=17–21, 29 }}</ref> Sears is a decided advocate for [[Parenting styles#Authoritative parenting|authoritative parenting]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |pages=237f}}; {{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=106 }}</ref>
As studies have shown, it is indeed possible to use discipline strategies that are sensitive<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Van Zeijl |first1=J. |last2=Mesman |first2=J. |last3=Van Ijzendoorn |first3=M.H. |last4=Bakermans-Kranenburg |first4=M. J. |last5=Juffer |first5=F. |last6=Stolk |first6=M. N. |last7=Alink |first7=L. R. |title=Attachment-based intervention for enhancing sensitive discipline in mothers of 1-to 3-year-old children at risk for externalizing behavior problems: a randomized controlled trial |journal=Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology |year=2006 |volume=74 |issue=6 |pages=994–1005 |pmid=17154730 |doi=10.1037/0022-006x.74.6.994}}</ref> and, therefore, one should not equate discipline and insensitive caregiving.
== In theory ==
=== Claim === Like Benjamin Spock before them, William and Martha Sears consider their parenting philosophy as a [[common sense]] and instinct-guided [[ad hoc]] way of parenting.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=William |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Hachette |location=New York |year=2001 |isbn=978-0-7595-2603-7 |pages=5 }}</ref> In contrast to Spock who derived his ideas in a straight line from [[Sigmund Freud|Freud]]’s [[psychoanalysis]], the Searses in fact didn’t start out from a [[theory]]; even the tie to attachment theory was only engineered ex post, when the philosophy was already largely complete. Apart from Liedloff’s rather eclectic thoughts, they came to their ideas mainly from their own personal impressions:<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=2f, 8, 10, 26f }}</ref>
{{ Quotation |Our ideas about attachment parenting are based on thirty-plus years of parenting our own eight children and observing moms and dads whose parenting choices seemed to make sense and whose children we liked. We have witnessed the effects this approach to parenting has on children. |Bill Sears, Martha Sears<ref name="apb_ix" /> }}
Despite the lack of a consistent theory, William and Martha Sears consider attachment parenting scientifically proven:
{{ Quotation | AP is not only common sense, it’s supported by science. |Bill Sears, Martha Sears<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=11 }}</ref> }}
Their belief in such scientific proof doesn’t hinder the Searses to advise AP parents not to engage in discussions with AP critics.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=127f }}</ref> They also favor some science while they refuse other:
{{ Quotation | Science says: Good Science Backs AP. |Bill Sears, Martha Sears<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=120 }}</ref> }}
=== Fundamental terms and criticism === Critics consider a lack of a consistent theoretical foundation – notably the lack of precise definitions of the fundamental terms – a shortcoming of the attachment parenting concept.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ahaparenting.com/parenting-tools/attachment-parenting/Pros-and-cons |title=Attachment Parenting Pros and Cons}} {{cite web |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2014/08/the-perils-of-attachment-parenting/375198/ |title=The Perils of Attachment Parenting }} {{cite web |url=http://www.parentingscience.com/attachment-parenting.html |title=The science of attachment parenting}} {{cite web |url=http://childrensmd.org/browse-by-age-group/toddler-pre-school/attunement-parenting-the-new-attachment-parenting/ |title="Attunement Parenting"—The New Attachment Parenting}}</ref>
==== Sensitivity ==== [[File:Mother-Child face to face.jpg|thumb|Contingency: Mother and child in emotional harmony]] The concept of mutual emotional fine-tuning has been known in [[psychology]] since [[Franz Mesmer]], who introduced it under the term "[[rapport]]", before Freud adopted it for psychoanalysis. In relation to the mother-child-tie, [[behaviorism|behaviorists]] and developmental psychologists rather speak of "contingency" today; [[Daniel Stern (psychologist)|Daniel Stern]] coined the term "attunement", too.
For Williams Sears, attachment parenting is a kind of parenting that is radically characterized by maternal responsivity. For that, he adopted [[Mary Ainsworth]]’s term of "maternal [[sensitivity (human)|sensitivity]]": The woman directs her attention completely on the child ("[[#Babyreading|babyreading]]") and responds continuously to every signal that the child sends; the result is a state of harmony between mother and child that leads to mutual attachment.<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |pages=29, 67ff, 107, 184}}; {{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=2, 5, 7ff }}</ref> Sears believes that the maternal "tuning-in" begins during pregnancy already.<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |pages=43}}</ref>
==== Attachment ==== Within the framework of [[infant cognitive development]] studies, the child's [[Attachment in children|attachment]] to the parents has been well researched. As early as in the late 1940s, [[Donald Winnicott]] gave a detailed account of the development of the child's attachment; at the latest after the sixth month, healthy children begin to disengage from the mother-child symbiosis quite normally. However, it was [[Margaret Mahler]] who gave the most accurate description of the attachment development during the first three years. William Sears’ publications reveal no knowledge of this relevant literature.
Sears’ use of the term "attachment" is merely [[colloquialism|colloquial]]. He applies it synonymously with terms like [[trust (social sciences)|trust]], harmony, closeness, [[Affectional bond|bonding]], love bonds, and connection: ''"Attachment describes the whole caregiving relationship between mother or father and baby."''<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=36 }}; {{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |pages=71, 189}}</ref> He mentions that attachment emerges from contingency, but in his further accounts, he never differentiates between attachment and contingency. The readers must therefore assume that attachment is a deeply vulnerable state that never stabilizes and that requires constant reestablishment through incessant sensitivity.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=5, 8f, 11, 16, 20, 23, 36–39, 45ff, 49, 92, 130 }}</ref>
Later in the book, in contradiction to his own preceding statements, Sears reassures [[Adoption|adoptive parents]]: ''"Don't worry about the attachment your child may have ’missed’ in foster care. Infants are extremely [[Psychological resilience|resilient]]."''<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=161 }}</ref>
==== Insecure attachment ==== The establishment of a secure mother-child attachment is the declared and pivotal goal of attachment parenting.
In numerous scientific studies, the normal development of attachment has been well documented. The same applies for deviant or pathological developments. Problematic or disturbed attachment has been described in three contexts: *In extreme and rare conditions, the child may not form an attachment at all and may suffer from [[reactive attachment disorder]].<ref>Schechter D.S and E. Willheim (2009). "Disturbances of attachment and parental psychopathology in early childhood". [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2690512/ Child and Adolescent Psychiatric Clinics of North America 18 (3): 665–86]</ref> Children who suffer from reactive attachment disorder have often experienced extremely traumatic childhoods with a lot of neglect and abuse. An example of such a case is for children in orphanages in Romania where babies have been known to be left for 18–20 hours by themselves in their cribs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/24/magazine/the-disconnected-attachment-theory-the-ultimate-experiment.html|title=The Disconnected; Attachment Theory: The Ultimate Experiment|date = 1998-05-24|access-date = 2015-04-14|website = The New York Times|publisher = The New York Times|last = Talbot|first = Margaret}}</ref> As adults, people with reactive attachment disorder show severe emotional abnormalities and a severely impaired social behavior. *Mary Ainsworth described a type of [[Attachment theory#Attachment patterns|disorganized attachment]] that appears, too, mostly in children who suffered [[child abuse]]; boys are more frequently affected than girls.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Carlson |first=Vikko |title=Disorganized/disoriented attachment relationships in maltreated infants | journal=Developmental Psychology |volume=25 |issue=4 |year=July 1989 |pages=525–531 |url=http://psycnet.apa.org/journals/dev/25/4/525/ |doi=10.1037/0012-1649.25.4.525}}</ref> Those children show distress, and their mothers reveal an obvious lack of [[empathy]].<ref name="beebe">{{cite journal |last=Beebe |first=Beatrice |title=The origins of 12-month attachment: A microanalysis of 4-month mother-infant interaction | journal=Attachment & Human Development |volume=12 |year=2010 |pages=1–135 |pmc=3763737 |pmid=20390524 |doi=10.1080/14616730903338985 |issue=1–2}}</ref> Disorganized attachment is no mental disturbance in terms of [[International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems|ICD]], but a type of behavior that can be observed in the [[strange situation]] test only. In "normal" middle-class families, about 15% of all children show a disorganized attachment. In social problem groups, the percentage can be significantly higher.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=van Ijzendoorn |first1=Marinus |last2=Schuengel |first2=Carlo |last3=Bakermans-Kranenburg |first3=Marian J. |title=Disorganized attachment in early childhood: Meta-analysis of precursors, concomitants, and sequelae |journal=Development and Psychopathology |year=June 1999|issue=2 |pages=225–250 |url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=43645&fileId=S0954579499002035 | doi = 10.1017/s0954579499002035 }}</ref> [[File:Attachment types - USA Germany Japan.JPG|thumb|Secure, insecure-avoidant, and insecure-ambivalent attachment in toddlers in the U.S., in Germany, and Japan<ref name="IK">{{cite journal |last1=van Ijzendoorn |first1=M. H. |last2=Kroonenberg |first2=P. M. |title=Cross-cultural patterns of attachment: A meta-analysis of the strange situation |journal=Child Development |volume=59 |year=1988 |pages=147–156 |doi=10.2307/1130396|jstor=1130396 }}</ref>]] *A third group of problematic attachment is constituted by the types of [[Attachment theory#Attachment patterns|insecure-avoidant]] and [[Attachment theory#Attachment patterns|insecure-ambivalent attachment]], both described by Mary Ainsworth, too. Children who are insecurely attached behave in the strange situation test either aloof towards their mothers, or they fluctuate between clinginess and rejection. As Beatrice Beebe ([[Columbia University]]) has substantiated in a study in 2010, these children experience from their mothers constantly behavior like under- or overstimulation, intrusiveness or volatility. Nonetheless, their mothers displayed empathy and were fully able to respond to their children's emotional expressions appropriately; the children showed no signs of emotional distress.<ref name="beebe"/> Insecure attachment as defined by Ainsworth is very common and applies for example in the U. S. to about 1 out of 3 children.<ref name="IK" />
William Sears uses the terms "lesser quality of attachment", "insecure attachment", and "non-attachment" synonymously. His formulations don't reveal which kind of problematic attachment is meant: reactive attachment disorder (ICD), desorganized attachment (Ainsworth) or the two forms of insecure attachment (Ainsworth).<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |pages=183}}; {{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=William |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book : A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Hachette |location=New York |year=2001 |isbn=978-0-7595-2603-7 |pages=16f}}; {{cite web |url=http://www.attachmentparenting.org/support/articles/artadoption.php |title= Developing emotional attachments in adopted children |accessdate=2014-01-14 |publisher=Attachment Parenting International |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080708191012/http://www.attachmentparenting.org/support/articles/artadoption.php |archivedate = 2008-07-08}}</ref> Still in 1982, he mentioned "diseases of non-attachment" not referring to the attachment theorists [[John Bowlby|Bowlby]] and Ainsworth, but to Selma Fraiberg, a psychoanalyst who studied blindly born children in the 1970s.<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |pages=71}}</ref> Due to the vague description of problematic attachment, Sears and AP organisations who use his criteria have been reproached to produce a high rate of ''[[False positives and false negatives|false positives]]''.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Prior |first1=Vivien |last2=Glaser |first2=Danya |title=Understanding Attachment and Attachment Disorders : Theory, Evidence and Practice |publisher=Jessica Kingsley |location=London |year=2006 |isbn=1-84310-245-5 |pages=186 }}; {{cite journal |last=Chaffin |first=M. |title=Report of the APSAC Task Force on Attachment Therapy, Reactive Attachment Disorder, and Attachment Problems |journal=Child Maltreatment |volume=11 |issue=1 |year=2006 |pages=76–89 |doi=10.1177/1077559505283699 |pmid=16382093}}</ref> The same applies to definitions of [[attachment therapy]], a concept that frequently appears to be partially overlapping with attachment parenting.<ref>{{Cite book| author = Prior V and Glaser D| title = Understanding Attachment and Attachment Disorders: Theory, Evidence and Practice| year = 2006| series = Child and Adolescent Mental Health Series| publisher = Jessica Kingsley|page=186| location = London| isbn = 1-84310-245-5| oclc = 70663735}}; {{Cite journal |doi=10.1177/1077559505283699 |title=Report of the APSAC Task Force on Attachment Therapy, Reactive Attachment Disorder, and Attachment Problems |year=2006 |last=Chaffin |first=M. |journal=Child Maltreatment |volume=11 |pages=76–89 |pmid=16382093 |last2=Hanson |first2=R |last3=Saunders |first3=BE |last4=Nichols |first4=T |last5=Barnett |first5=D |last6=Zeanah |first6=C |last7=Berliner |first7=L |last8=Egeland |first8=B |last9=Newman |first9=E |issue=1 |last10=Lyon |first10=T |last11=Letourneau |first11=E |last12=Miller-Perrin |first12=C}}</ref> Attachment parenting supporters have distanced themselves from attachment therapy, notably from its methods, but not from its diagnostic criteria.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.attachmentparenting.org/apifaqs/myths-facts/attachmenttherapy |title=Is Attachment Parenting the same as attachment therapy? |access-date=2016-03-23 }} {{cite journal |doi=10.1177/1077559506292635 |title=An Elaboration on the Distinction Between Controversial Parenting and Therapeutic Practices Versus Developmentally Appropriate Attachment Parenting: A Comment on the APSAC Task Force Report |year=2006 |last1=Curtner-Smith |first1=M. E. |last2=Middlemiss |first2=W. |last3=Green |first3=K. |last4=Murray |first4=A. D. |last5=Barone |first5=M. |last6=Stolzer |first6=J. |last7=Parker |first7=L. |last8=Nicholson |first8=B. |journal=Child Maltreatment |volume=11 |issue=4 |pages=373–4; author reply 381–6 |pmid=17043322}}</ref>
Sears offers a discrimation between (good) attachment and (bad) [[enmeshment]], but again without explaining to his readers how exactly they can identify the difference.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=108f }}</ref>
There is no conclusive body of research that shows Sears’ approach to be superior to "mainstream parenting".<ref>{{cite journal |first1=Sharon |last1=Hays |year=1998 |title=The Fallacious Assumptions and Unrealistic Prescriptions of Attachment Theory: A Comment on 'Parents' Socioemotional Investment in Children' |journal=Journal of Marriage and Family |volume=60 |issue=3 |pages=782–90 |jstor=353546 |doi=10.2307/353546}}</ref> In [[field research|field studies]] in [[Uganda]], Ainsworth has observed that sometimes even children who spend plenty of time with their mothers and who were breastfed on cue, developed signs of insecure attachment; she concluded that it is not the quantity of mother-child interaction that determines the attachment type, but the quality.
