It is, therefore, not practices like co-sleeping, babywearing or feeding on cue that Ainsworth identifies as the crucial determinant for a secure attachment, but the ''maternal sensitivity''.<ref>{{cite book |last=Karen |first=Robert |title=Becoming Attached: First Relationships and How They Shape Our Capacity of Love |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=New York, Oxford |year=1998 |isbn=978-0-19-511501-7 |pages=139ff }}; {{cite book |last=Ainsworth |first=Mary |title=Infancy in Uganda: Infant Care and the Growth of Love |publisher=Johns Hopkins Press |location= |year=1967 |isbn=978-0801800108 }}; {{cite journal |last1=Kazuko |first1=B. |last2=Behrens |first2=Y. |last3=Parker |first3=Andrea C. |last4=Kulkofsky |first4=Sarah |title=Stability of Maternal Sensitivity Across Time and Contexts with Q-Sort Measures |journal=Infant and Child Development |volume=23 |issue=5 |year=2014 |pages=532–541 }}</ref>
==== Need ==== [[File:Lactancia en tandem 1.jpg|thumb|William Sears assumes that even toddlers can have a need for breastfeeding.]] The theoretical starting point of attachment parenting – the idea of contingency – would suggest a concept of the infant as a creature who is essentially defined by his ''feelings'' and his ''communication''. William Sears, though, defines infants even more essentially by their ''[[need]]s''.<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |pages=162, 182}}; {{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=12, 84, 90, 95 }}</ref> Need is therefore another basic term; attachment parenting means quintessentially to attend to the child's needs.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=1, 5, 7f, 10, 27, 31, 41–43, 78, 83f, 106ff, 131, 151, 155, 157 }}</ref>
As early as in the 1940s, psychologists such as [[Abraham Maslow]] shaped detailed models of the human needs; ever since, scientists have made a clear distinction between needs on the one hand and [[desire]]s on the other hand. In 2000, [[T. Berry Brazelton]], a pioneer in the field of newborn psychology, and child psychiatrist [[Stanley Greenspan]] published their book ''The Irreducible Needs of Children'', in which they re-assessed the term for pediatrics. When the Searses published their ''Attachment Parenting Book'' one year later, they responded neither to Maslow nor to Brazelton and Greenspan, but used the word ''need'' merely in a colloquial sense. Although they stressed that parents must distinguish between ''needs'' and ''desires'' of children, in particular of older children, they denied their readers a guideline of how to tell needs and desires apart.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=9, 28, 31, 101, 115, 118 }}</ref> With a view to infants, they believe that needs and desires are plainly identical.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=50 }}</ref> In general, they use both terms synonymously.<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |pages=167}}; {{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=23, 29, 30, 32, 44, 56, 60, 74, 77, 144 }}</ref> With a view to toddlers, they often phrase it: a child is ''not ready yet'' (to do without breastfeeding, without co-sleeping, etc.); but even in contexts like these, they speak of ''needs'', too.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=63, 97f, 101 }}; {{cite book |last1=Granju |first1=Katie Allison |last2=Kennedy |first2=Betsy |title=Attachment Parenting: Instinctive Care for Your Baby and Young Child |location=New York, NY |publisher=Pocket Books |year=1999 |isbn=0-671-02762-X |pages=6 }}</ref>
Opponents of attachment parenting have questioned that the behavior of a 3½ year old who still demands to nurse can actually be classified as a ''need''. Most likely the child is seeking [[consolation]]. To give a child comfort is an important parental responsibility; but parents are just as well liable to teach their child to take heart by his own power.<ref name="savvy">{{cite web | url=http://www.savvymom.ca/index.php/expert_blog/attachment-parenting |title=Attachment Parenting |access-date=2015-01-23 }}</ref>
==== Stress ==== [[File:Waaah!.jpg|thumb|Should parents give comfort or teach composure?]] [[Stress (psychological)|Stress]] has been surveyed and documented in many studies. The theoretical foundation was created in the 1960s by [[Richard Lazarus]]. In 1974, [[Hans Selye]] introduced the differentiation between [[Stress (psychological)#Distress|distress]] and [[eustress]], and in 1984, psychoanalyst [[Heinz Kohut]] proposed the concept of ''optimal frustration''; Kohut postulated that the harmony between parents and child needs some well allotted disruption in order to empower the child to develop a healthy [[personality]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Kohut |first=Heinz |title=How Does Analysis Cure? |location=Chicago |publisher=University of Chicago Press |year=1984 }}</ref> In [[Psychological resilience|resilience psychology]], too, there is broad agreement today that it harms children if their parents keep any stress away from them indiscriminately; by doing so, they suggest to the child that everyday problems are painful and overall to be avoided.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.csaschool.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/helicopter-parents-article-with-Jan-08-letter.pdf |last=Cooper |first=Carolyn C. |title=Band-aids, Safety Nets, and Escape Routes: How "Helicopter Parents" May Be Harming Their Children |access-date=2015-11-28 }}</ref>
Even though stress is one of the fundamental terms of attachment parenting, William Sears’ publications don't reveal acquaintance with pertinent literature about this topic.<ref name="savvy"/> Sears links stress and distress with the release of [[cortisol]], but uses both terms synonymously and in a purely colloquial sense. He refers the term to any uncomfortable or frustrating state which makes the child cry – a signal which AP mothers are supposed to carefully attend to since stress sickens the child.<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |pages=182}}; {{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=15, 17f, 38, 40, 63, 83–85 }}</ref> On the other hand, Sears advises mothers not to overreact and to teach the child imperturbation ("Caribbean approach").<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=83, 87 }}</ref> He leaves it up to the parents to decide which type of response individual situations ask for.
For parenting, any fuzziness of the term ''stress'' as well as of the term ''need'' have far-reaching consequences. If it is assumed that any crying of the child indicates harmful stress and that any of his demands indicate a true need, parents are bound to confuse rapport, sensitivity, responsivity, emotional availability, and wise protection with behaviors that, from an educational standpoint, are highly dysfunctional and that William Sears mostly wouldn't agree with himself: *with anxious continuous monitoring of the child<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=15, 77 }}</ref> *with [[Helicopter parent|over-parenting]], that is the continuous removal of such problems which the child could actually cope with herself<ref>{{cite book |last=Mogel |first=Wendy |title=The Blessings of a Skinned Knee |year=2001 }}; {{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=14 }}</ref> *with continuous [[micromanagement]] of the child's [[Mood (psychology)|moods]], aimed to keep the child [[Happiness|happy]] around the clock;<ref>{{cite book |last=Kang |first=Shimi |title=Das Delfin-Prinzip. Gute Erziehung – glückliche und starke Kinder |publisher=Mosaik |year=2014 |isbn=978-3-641-12163-1 |pages=23 }}; {{cite journal | url=http://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/the-narcissism-epidemic/201205/it-s-not-the-breastfeeding-s-wrong-it-s-the-indulgence |title= It’s Not the Breastfeeding That’s Wrong; It’s the Indulgence |journal=Psychology Today|date=2012-05-11 |access-date=2015-01-17}} ; {{cite news | url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2011/07/how-to-land-your-kid-in-therapy/308555/ |last=Gottlieb |first =Lori |title=How to Land Your Kid in Therapy|newspaper=The Atlantic|date= 2011-06-07 |access-date=2015-01-16}}.</ref> indeed, William Sears considers happiness ''"the end result and the bottom line of child-rearing"''.<ref name="happy">{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |pages=197 }}</ref>
==== Instinct and nature ==== [[File:Mali - Mother with baby.jpg|thumb|Mother with child in [[Mali]] (2006)]] [[Instinct]] is another basic term of attachment parenting. The Searses describe attachment parenting as the [[Nature|natural]], biological, [[intuition|intuitive]] and spontaneous behavior of mothers who rely on their instincts, [[Extrasensory perception|sixth sense]], inner wisdom or [[common sense]].<ref name="natur">{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |pages=29, 32, 45, 88, 91f, 96, 166, 176, 241}}; {{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=ix, 1, 3ff, 7f, 11, 16f, 23, 26, 30, 34, 36, 38f, 48, 53, 56, 70, 84, 86, 120f, 124, 147, 155 }}</ref> They attribute even motherliness itself to instincts,<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=8 }}</ref> whereas they attest [[Man|men]] a reduced instinct for children's needs.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=114, 153 }}</ref>
Instinct theory developed in the 1930s within the framework of [[ethology]]. It owes its basic ideas to [[William McDougall (psychologist)|William McDougall]] among others, and its elaboration mainly to [[Konrad Lorenz]] and [[Nikolaas Tinbergen]]. Lorenz believed that instincts are physiological processes, and assumed they could be described as neuronal circuitry in the brain. But already [[Arnold Gehlen]] had disputed that humans still have much instinct at their disposal; for him, plasticity and learning aptitude outranked instinct.<ref>{{cite book |last=Gehlen |first=Arnold |title=Anthropologische Forschung |publisher=Rowohlt |location=Reinbek |year=1961}}</ref> In today's research, the term instinct is regarded as absolete.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/topic/instinct.aspx |title=encyclopedia.com: Instinct |access-date=2015-11-20}}</ref> Recent studies have demonstrated that motherly behavior is not inbred but biologically and socially determined.<ref>{{cite book|last=Blaffer-Hrdy |first=Sarah |title=A History of Mothers, Infants, and Natural Selection |publisher=Pantheon |year=1999 |isbn=0-679-44265-0 }}</ref> It is partly triggered by [[oxytocin]], partly learned.<ref>{{cite magazine | url=http://www.spiegel.de/wissenschaft/mensch/mutterliebe-das-staerkste-gefuehl-entschluesselt-a-415306.html |title=Mutterliebe: Das stärkste Gefühl entschlüsselt|magazine=Der Spiegel|date=2006-05-14 |access-date=2015-01-29}} ; {{cite web | url=http://health.howstuffworks.com/pregnancy-and-parenting/is-mothering-instinctive-or-learned.htm |title=Is mothering instinctive or learned? |access-date=2015-01-29}}; {{cite journal |last1=Kinsley |first1=Craig Howard |last2=Lambert |first2=Kelly G. |title=The Maternal Brain |journal=Scientific American |volume=294 |year=January 2006 |pages=72–79 |url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/the-maternal-brain/ |doi=10.1038/scientificamerican0106-72}}; {{cite web | url=http://www.apa.org/news/press/releases/2010/10/mommy-brain.aspx |title=The Real ‘Mommy Brain’: New Mothers Grew Bigger Brains Within Months of Giving Birth |access-date=2015-01-29}}</ref>
William Sears' writings show no knowledge of this current state of research. The Searses use the word instinct in a purely colloquial sense and synonymous with terms like ''hormonal'' and ''natural'';<ref name="natur"/> as an antipole of instinct and nature, they identify the things that "childcare advisors" say.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=26f, 120 }}</ref>
{{Quotation|If you were on an island, and you had no mothers-in-law, no psychologists, no doctors around, no experts, this is what you would naturally and instinctively do to give your baby the best investment you'll ever give.|William Sears, Martha Sears<ref name="Little, Brown and Company">{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=27 }}</ref>}}
William Sears, who owes his formative impressions to Jean Liefloff, points to mammals, [[primate]]s, "other", "primitive", and "traditional cultures", namely on [[Bali]] and in [[Zambia]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=26, 60, 62, 65–68, 74, 79, 89, 110, 122 }}</ref> Developmental psychologist Heidi Keller who comparatively researched the mother-child relationship in a large bandwidth of cultures, disputes that attachment parenting can be described as a return to a "natural motherliness", like many supporters advertise it. Keller doesn't rank attachment parenting as a counteragent to the high-tech world, but asserts that it ''"paradoxically fits optimally into a society of individualists and lone warriors how we experience it in the Western world"''. Many of the methods that the representatives of attachment parenting attribute to the [[evolutionary history of life]] don't actually play the major role in non-western cultures that is attributed to them. In [[Cameroon]] for example, children are actually carried in a sling initially, but then have to learn to sit and to walk much earlier than European and North American children; rather than to cultivate affectionate eye contact, mothers blow into their children's face in order to get them out of the habit of making eye contact.<ref name="urform">{{cite web | url=http://www.fr-online.de/wissenschaft/umgang-mit-kindern--urform-der-mutterliebe-gibt-es-nicht-,1472788,25804470.html | title=Urform der Mutterliebe gibt es nicht | access-date=2015-01-13 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150114032752/http://www.fr-online.de/wissenschaft/umgang-mit-kindern--urform-der-mutterliebe-gibt-es-nicht-,1472788,25804470.html | archive-date=2015-01-14 | dead-url=yes | df= }}; {{cite web | url=http://respectfulparent.com/ten-problems-attachment-parenting/ | title=Ten Problems with Attachment Parenting | access-date=2015-01-13 }}; {{cite web | url=http://afterthemillennials.com/2012/06/04/the-mommy-wars-did-modern-mothering-became-a-monastic-servitude-contest/ | title=The mommy wars – did modern mothering become a monastic servitude contest? | access-date=2015-01-20 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150120221636/http://afterthemillennials.com/2012/06/04/the-mommy-wars-did-modern-mothering-became-a-monastic-servitude-contest/ | archive-date=2015-01-20 | dead-url=yes | df= }}</ref>
[[File:Navajo papoose on a cradleboard with a lamb approaching, Window Rock, Arizona, 1936 - NARA - 519160.jpg|thumb|[[Navajo]] baby on a cradleboard (1936)]] Even in the [[United States]], there are [[minority groups]] which can be classified as highly "traditional", none of them practicing attachment parenting. [[Amish]] mothers for example co-sleep with their infants, but only for the first several months;<ref>{{cite book |last=Wittmer |first=Joe |chapter=Counseling the Old Order Amish: Culturally Different by Religion |editor1-last=Vacc |editor1-first=Nicolas A. |editor2-last=DeVaney |editor2-first=Susan B. |editor3-last=Brendel |editor3-first=Johnston M. |title=Counseling Multicultural and Diverse Populations: Stragegies for Practitioners |publisher=Routledge |location=Hove, East Sussex|edition=4th |year=2003 |isbn=978-1583913482 |pages=307–324 (315)}}</ref> they never let their infants and toddlers out of view, but they don't wear them while they are working.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.amishnews.com/amisharticles/amishchildren.htm |title=Amish Children: Nurturing & Belonging |access-date=2016-03-20 }}</ref> From very early on, Amish children are raised to serve God, family, and community rather than to express their own needs.<ref>{{cite book |title=Encyclopedia of Medical Anthropology : Health and Illness in the World's Cultures |editor1-last=Ember |editor1-first=Carol R. |editor2-last=Ember |editor2-first=Melvin |publisher=Kluwer Academic/Plenum |location=New York, Boston, Dordrecht, London, Moscow |year=2004 |isbn=0-306-47754-8 |pages=562}}</ref> The infants of [[Orthodox Judaism|orthodox Jews]] traditionally sleep in [[Cradle (bed)|cradles]].<ref>{{cite book |title=The Jewish Encyclopedia |volume=6 |publisher=Funk and Wagnalls |location=New York, London |year=1912|page=443}}</ref> In communities where there is no ''[[eruv]]'', Jewish parents are not allowed to carry their children about on [[Shabbat]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chabad.org/library/article_cdo/aid/77897/jewish/Baby-and-Toddler-Care-on-Shabbat.htm#footnote41a77897 |last1=Greisman |first1=Nechoma |last2=Ne'eman |first2=Chana |title= Baby and Toddler Care on Shabbat |access-date=2016-03-21 }} {{cite book |title=How ro Run a Traditional Jewish Household |last=Blu |first=Greenberg |publisher=Ttouchstone |year=1985 |isbn=978-0671602703}}</ref> [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] traditionally used [[cradleboard]]s which could be worn, but which involved minimal physical touch of mother and child.
=== Optimal development of the child === As Suzanne M. Cox ([[Northwestern University]]) has pointed out, neither attachment theory nor attachment parenting offer a general outline of the optimal development of the child, which could be used to empirically measure the efficacy of attachment parenting.<ref name="cox">Cox, Suzanne M.: ''Bridging Attachment Theory and Attachment Parenting with Feminist Methods of Inquiry.'' 2006.</ref> The Searses promise parenting results such as increased independence, [[confidence]], health, physical growth, improved development of the [[motor skill|motor]] and [[language development|language skills]], [[etiquette|good manners]], [[conscientiousness]], [[social competence]], sense of justice, [[altruism]], sensitivity, empathy, [[attentional control|concentration]], [[self-control]], and [[intelligence]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |pages=182}}; {{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=11–25, 32–34, 71f, 152, 164 }} On his website, Sears even suggests that with attachment parenting, there would have been no [[The Holocaust|Holocaust]]: {{cite web | url=http://www.askdrsears.com/topics/parenting/discipline-behavior/attachment-parenting-discipline |title=10 Ways Attachment Parenting Discipline is Easier |access-date=2015-01-29}}</ref> However, there is no conclusive evidence from empirical research that supports such claims.<ref name="cox"/>
The ultimate target of child rearing is, according to Sears, [[happiness]].<ref name="happy"/> Similar to the German [[Catholic Church|catholic]] Albert Wunsch, Sears therefore ranks among those parenting advisors whose philosophies reflect stray aspects of their [[Belief#Religion|religious beliefs]], but result in a purely worldly target. In the year of the publication of the ''Attachment Parenting Book'', [[Wendy Mogel]], by contrast, suggested her own very influential concept of [[character education]] that was straightforwardly based on her [[Judaism|Jewish faith]] (''The Blessings of a Skinned Knee'', 2001).
== Distribution and acceptance == [[File:Manuela Schwesig (15321053638).jpg|thumb|In 2014, German [[Federal Ministry of Family Affairs, Senior Citizens, Women and Youth|Federal Minister of Family Affairs]], [[Manuela Schwesig]], was patron of the first Attachment Parenting Congress in Germany.]] Attachment parenting is particularly popular among educated urban women in Western countries, who are interested in [[ecology|ecological]] and [[social]] issues.<ref name="urform"/>
In the [[United States]], parenting tips of well-known people like the actresses [[Mayim Bialik]] and [[Alicia Silverstone]] contributed to the popularity of the philosophy.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-families/features/mayim-bialik-from-big-bang-theory-to-attachment-parenting-9778544.html |last=Bialik |first=Mayim |title=From Big Bang Theory to attachment parenting |access-date=2015-01-14 }} {{cite book |last=Bialik |first=Mayim |title=Beyond the Sling. A Real-Life Guide to Raising Confident, Loving Children the Attachment Parenting Way |publisher=Touchstone |year=2012 |isbn= 978-1-4516-6218-4 }} {{cite web | url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/xx_factor/2014/04/24/alicia_silverstone_writes_a_parenting_book_enough_with_the_celebrity_mom.html | title=Celebrity Quack Moms Are a Terrible Influence on Everyday Parents | access-date=2015-01-29 }}; {{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Lifestyle/celebs-attachment-parent/story?id=23176780 |title=6 Celebs Who Attachment Parent |access-date=2015-01-21 |newspaper=ABC News |date=2014-04-03 }}; {{cite web | url= http://www.babble.com/celebrity/kimya-dawson-moldy-peaches-alphabutt-and-attachment-parenting/ | title= Kimya Dawson of the Moldy Peaches Talks Attachment Parenting | access-date= 2015-01-21 | deadurl= yes | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150128113651/http://www.babble.com/celebrity/kimya-dawson-moldy-peaches-alphabutt-and-attachment-parenting/ | archivedate= 2015-01-28 | df= }}; {{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/lifestyle/2012/03/hollywood-star-talks-about-co-sleeping-baby-wearing-and-unschooling/ |title=Hollywood Star Talks About Co-Sleeping, Baby-Wearing and Unschooling |access-date=2015-02-14 |newspaper=ABC News |date=2012-03-05 }}</ref> Many North American Women are organized in support groups of ''Attachment Parenting International'' (API), the movement's umbrella organization, in which Martha Sears serves as a [[Board of directors|board member]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.attachmentparenting.org/ |title=Attachment Parenting International |access-date=2016-03-18 }}</ref> In [[Canada]], there are further AP organizations such as the ''Attachment Parenting Canada Association'' ([[Calgary]]);<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.attachmentparenting.ca/ |title=Attachment Parenting Canada Association |access-date=2015-11-26}}</ref> even some public health organizations promote attachment parenting.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.saskatoonhealthregion.ca/locations_services/Services/Healthy-Families/Documents/HF-91%20Attachment%20Parenting.pdf |title= Saskatoon Health Region: Attachment Parenting |access-date=2016-01-11 }}</ref> William Sears has close ties to the international [[La Leche League]] (LLL) which feature him as a conference speaker and published several of his books.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/breastfeeding-childbirth-and-parenting-experts-gather-for-la-leche-league-international-50th-anniversary-conference-52722802.html |title=Breastfeeding, Childbirth and Parenting Experts Gather for La Leche League International 50th Anniversary Conference |access-date=2015-01-14}}; {{cite web | url=http://www.lllofwa.org/2012/05/time-magazine-response |title=La Leche League of Washington's response to Time Magazine May cover |access-date=2015-01-14}}</ref> In LLL groups, many mothers get in touch with attachment parenting for the first time.<ref>{{cite book |last=Dodd |first=Sandra|title=Big Book of Unschooling |edition=3. |year=2009 |isbn=978-0-557-18155-1 |pages=57 }}</ref> There are also attachment parenting organizations in [[Australia]] and in [[New Zealand]].
In Europe, ''Attachment Parenting Europe'' (APEU, in [[Lelystad]], Netherlands) campaigns for attachment parenting; in the [[Dutch language]] the philosophy is referred to as ''natuurlijk ouderschap'' (''natural parenthood''). This organization keeps liaisons to representatives in [[Belgium]], [[Denmark]], Germany, [[Ireland]], [[Italy]], [[Norway]], the [[United Kingdom]], and [[Switzerland]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.attachmentparenting.eu/ |title=Attachment Parenting Europe |access-date=2015-02-28}}</ref> In 2012, there were 30 AP groups in [[England]] and [[Wales]].<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2012/may/21/attachment-parenting-whats-the-problem |title=Attachment parenting: what's the problem? |access-date=2015-01-21 |newspaper=The Guardian |date=2012-05-21 }}</ref>
In Germany, there are independent AP institutions in several cities.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.erdbeerkinder-hamburg.de/ |title=Erbeerkinder Hamburg |access-date=2015-01-30}}; {{cite web | url=http://www.einfach-eltern.de/ |title=Einfach Eltern |access-date=2015-01-30}}</ref> [[Hamburg]], the movement's central point in Germany, hosted a first ''Attachment Parenting Congress'' in 2014, under the patronage of Federal Minister of Family Affairs, Manuela Schwesig.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.attachment-parenting-kongress.de/ |title=Attachment Parenting Kongress 2014 |access-date=2015-01-21}}</ref> A second one has been announced for 2016.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.attachment-parenting-kongress.de/ |title=Attachment Parenting Kongress 2016 |access-date=2015-06-16 }}</ref>
In [[Austria]] and Switzerland there exist a small number of AP institutions, too.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.biolino.at/ |title=Webseite des Wiener Eltern-Kind-Zentrums Biolino |access-date=2015-02-28}}; {{cite web | url=http://www.verein-tragwerk.ch/ |title=Webseite des Vereins Tragwerk in Schaffhausen |access-date=2015-02-28 }}</ref> In [[Sweden]], fantasy and science fiction writer Jorun Modén solicits attachment parenting, which she refers to as ''nära föräldraskap'' (''proximal parenthood'').<ref>{{cite book |last=Modén |first=Jorun |title=Nära föräldrar |publisher=Tecknade bilder förlag |year=2005 |isbn=91-973692-3-3 }}; {{cite web | url=http://www.naraforaldrar.se/vadarnf.htm |title=Vad är Nära föräldraskap? |access-date=2015-02-14}}</ref> In [[France]] where the philosophy is dubbed as ''maternage intensif'' or ''maternage proximal'', the movement has virtually no followers;<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.phdinparenting.com/blog/2008/5/29/attachment-parenting-has-not-caught-on-in-france.html |title=Attachment parenting has not caught on in France |access-date=2015-01-30}}; {{cite web | url=http://www.parents.fr/Puericulture/Maternage/Les-hyper-meres-le-point-sur-le-maternage-intensif |title=Les hyper mères : le point sur le maternage intensif |access-date=2015-01-30}}; {{cite news | url=http://www.lemonde.fr/vous/article/2010/01/16/le-maternage-proximal-fait-des-adeptes-et-provoque-la-controverse_1292686_3238.html |title=Plus près de toi, mon bébé |access-date=2015-01-30 |newspaper=Le Monde |date=2010-01-16 }}</ref> due to the success of the [[Napoleon]]ic education reforms, the French traditionally have a deeply rooted belief that educated child care specialists educate children at least as well as mothers do.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.zeit.de/2016/07/vorurteile-meinungen-alltag-politik-werbung |last=Jessen |first=Jens|title=Meinung mit beschränkter Haftung | newspaper=[[Die Zeit]] |date=2016-02-11 |access-date=2016-03-10 }}</ref>
== {{Anchor|Controversy}}Controversy == Since 2012, there has been a controversy about Sears' positions which has been mostly carried out in the [[English-speaking world]].
It began in 2012 with a cover picture on the [[Time (magazine)|''Time'' magazine]] that showed a [[California]]n mother breastfeeding her almost 4-year-old. In the accompanying article ''The Man Who Remade Motherhood'', journalist Kate Pickert argued that even if William Sears' positions are much less radical than those of his followers, they are misogynic and give mothers a chronically guilty conscience, and that they frequently disagree with relevant research results.<ref name="pickCase">{{cite news |last=Pickert |first=Kate |title= The Man Who Remade Motherhood |newspaper=Time Magazine |date=2012-05-21 }} {{cite web | url=https://achildgrows.com/blog/2009/04/the-case-against-dr-sears/ |title=The Case Against Dr. Sears |access-date=2015-01-22 }}</ref> The cover picture and article became the starting point of agitated disputes in many media.
At the same time, attachment parenting attracted attention of [[sociology|sociologist]]s like Ellie Lee, Charlotte Faircloth, Jan Macvarish, and [[Frank Furedi]] who described the phenomenon an example of 21st century ''Parental Determinism''. As early as in 1996, sociologist Sharon Hays had described the sociocultural phenomenon of an ''Intensive Mothering''; with attachment parenting, this phenomenon finally became tangible and recognizable.<ref>{{cite book |last=Hays |first=Sharon |title=The Cultural Contradictions of Motherhood |publisher=Yale University Press |year=1996 }}</ref> In 2004, media critic [[Susan J. Douglas]] and philosopher Meredith W. Michaels followed with their account of a ''New Momism''.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Douglas |first1=Susan |last2=Michaels |first2=Meredith |title=The Mommy Myth. The Idealization of Motherhood and How It Has Undermined Women |publisher=Simon and Schuster |year=2004 }}</ref>
=== ''Time'' cover picture and article === ''Time'' cover picture and article were published May 21, 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://content.time.com/time/covers/0,16641,20120521,00.html |title=Are You Mom Enough? (Titelseite) |access-date=2015-01-21 }}; {{cite news |url=http://sz-magazin.sueddeutsche.de/blogs/promileaks/2115/der-busen-des-anstosses/ |last=Haas |first=Michaela |title=Der Busen des Anstoßes |newspaper=Süddeutsche Zeitung Magazin |date=2013-03-25 |access-date=2015-01-22 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Pickert described how parents who follow Sears tend to take opinions that are much more radical than Sears himself.<ref name="pickert">{{cite news |last=Pickert |first=Kate |title= The Man Who Remade Motherhood |newspaper=Time Magazine |date=2012-05-21 }}</ref> Nevertheless, many parents catch from Sears' books an outlook that Pickert jestingly describes as a ''"post-traumatic Sears disorder"'': a severe sense of insufficiency that seems to appear in particular in such mothers who ''want'' to follow Sears' advice, for the sake of their children's mental health, but ''cannot'', e.g. because they can't afford to be stay-at-home-moms.<ref name="pickCase"/>
=== "Parental tribalism" === [[Katha Pollitt]] referred to attachment parenting as a [[fad]].<ref name="pollitt">{{cite web | url= http://www.thenation.com/article/167928/attachment-parenting-more-guilt-mother# |title=Attachment Parenting: More Guilt for Mother |access-date=2015-01-23}}</ref> Parents who follow the philosophy have been reproached as acting according to their own helplessness and unsatisfied emotional neediness which may be the true reasons for their decision to incessantly pacify their child by breastfeeding and babywearing even into toddlerhood, as the belief that the child actually needs all that permanent intimacy for his healthy development is only a subterfuge.<ref>{{cite journal | url=http://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/the-narcissism-epidemic/201112/the-easiest-way-mess-your-child |title=The Easiest Way to Mess up Your Child | journal=Psychology Today|date=2011-12-14 |access-date=2015-01-17 }} {{cite web | url=http://www.psychalive.org/the-problem-with-narcissistic-parents/ |title=The Problem with Narcissistic Parents |access-date=2015-01-17 }}</ref> Emma Jenner argued that parents who are in the habit of stereotypically attending to each of the child's signals with physical proximity will not learn to perceive the child's needs in the full extend of their bandwidth and complexity.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2014/08/the-perils-of-attachment-parenting/375198/ |last=Jenner |first=Emma |title=The Perils of Attachment Parenting |access-date=2015-11-02}}</ref>
Katie Allison Granju, who advocates attachment parenting and who published comprehensive guidelines for AP parents, offers a different perspective. She characterizes attachment parenting as not just a parenting style, but ''"a completely fulfilling [[Lifestyle (sociology)|way of life]]"''.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Granju |first1=Katie Allison |last2=Kennedy |first2=Betsy |title=Attachment Parenting: Instinctive Care for Your Baby and Young Child |location=New York, NY |publisher=Pocket Books |year=1999 |isbn=0-671-02762-X |pages=10 }}</ref>
Sociologist Jan Macvarish ([[University of Kent]]), a pioneer in the recent field of parenting culture study, described how AP parents utilize their parenting philosophy as a strategy of individualization, as a way to find personal identity and to join a group of congenial adults. Macvarish even speaks of ''parental tribalism''. According to Macvarish, it is characteristic for such choices that they are much more angled towards the parents' self-perception than towards the child's needs.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.kent.ac.uk/chss/staff/research/macvarish.html | title=Jan Macvarish's web site | access-date=2015-01-25 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160118014948/http://www.kent.ac.uk/chss/staff/research/macvarish.html | archivedate=2016-01-18 | df= }}; {{cite web |url=http://www.skepticalob.com/2013/02/attachment-parenting-is-about-the-need-of-parents-for-validation-not-the-needs-of-children.html |title=Attachment parenting is about the need of parents for validation, not the needs of children |access-date=2015-01-25 }}</ref> Sociologist Charlotte Faircloth, too, considers attachment parenting a strategy that women pursue in order to gain and to express [[Identity formation|personal identity]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Faircloth |first=Charlotte |title=Militant Lactivism? Attachment parenting and intensive motherhood in the UK and France |publisher=Berghahn |location= |year=2013 |isbn=978-0-85745-758-5 |pages=15ff }}</ref>
=== Child-rearing and lifestyle preferences of AP parents === Multiple authors have stated that many parents choose attachment parenting as part of an individualization strategy and as a statement of personal identity and of social affiliation. This assumption is supported by the observation that most AP parents show further distinctive parenting and life style preferences that are based on a particular set of attitudes (notably: a striving for naturalness), which, however, are mostly not directly tied to the declared goal of attachment parenting:<ref>{{cite web | url=http://afterthemillennials.com/2012/06/04/the-mommy-wars-did-modern-mothering-became-a-monastic-servitude-contest/ | title=The mommy wars – did modern mothering become a monastic servitude contest? | access-date=2015-01-20 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150120221636/http://afterthemillennials.com/2012/06/04/the-mommy-wars-did-modern-mothering-became-a-monastic-servitude-contest/ | archive-date=2015-01-20 | dead-url=yes | df= }}; {{cite web |url=http://bringbirthhome.com/attachment-parenting/attachment-parenting-rules/ |title=Attachment Parenting Rules?! |access-date=2015-01-24 }}</ref> *"gentle" childbirth,<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |pages=39 }}</ref> "natural" childbirth, [[home birth]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://attachmentparenting.org/blog/2008/04/28/planning-for-a-home-birth/ |title=Planning for a home birth |access-date=2015-01-27}}; {{cite web | url=http://bringbirthhome.com/attachment-parenting/attachment-parenting-rules/ |title=Attachment Parenting Rules?! |access-date=2015-01-27}}</ref> *use of homemade toddler food from [[Organic food|organic ingredients]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.askdrsears.com/topics/feeding-eating/feeding-infants-toddlers |title=Feeding Infants and Toddlers |access-date=2015-01-24}}; {{cite web | url=http://www.askdrsears.com/topics/feeding-eating/family-nutrition/faqs-about-organic-foods |title=FAQ’s About Organic Foods |access-date=2015-01-24}}</ref> [[veganism]],<ref>{{cite book |last=Silverstone |first=Alicia |title=The Kind Mama: A Simple Guilde to Supercharged Fertility, a Radiant Pregnancy, a Sweeter Birth, and a Healthier, More Beautiful Beginning |publisher=Rodale Books |year=2014 |isbn=978-1-62336-040-5 }}</ref> [[paleolithic diet]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://paleoparents.com/2011/our-unsmothered-kids/ |title=Our unsmothered kids |access-date=2015-01-24}}</ref> * use of washable [[cloth diaper]]s;<ref>{{cite book |last1=Granju |first1=Katie Allison |last2=Kennedy |first2=Betsy |title=Attachment Parenting: Instinctive Care for Your Baby and Young Child |location=New York, NY |publisher=Pocket Books |year=1999 |isbn=0-671-02762-X |pages=134ff }} {{cite web | url=http://www.diaperdecisions.com/pages/attachmentparenting.php | title=Diaper decisions: Attachment Parenting as a Whole | access-date=2015-01-27 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150210114347/http://www.diaperdecisions.com/pages/attachmentparenting.php | archivedate=2015-02-10 | df= }}</ref> [[elimination communication]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/21/diaper-free-babies-elimination-communication_n_3125617.html |title=Elimination Communication: Diaper-Free Trend Gets First Ever Week-Long Celebration (POLL) |access-date=2015-01-27}}</ref> * "gentle discipline",<ref>{{cite book |last1=Granju |first1=Katie Allison |last2=Kennedy |first2=Betsy |title=Attachment Parenting: Instinctive Care for Your Baby and Young Child |location=New York, NY |publisher=Pocket Books |year=1999 |isbn=0-671-02762-X |pages=9 }} {{cite journal | url=http://www.llli.org/nb/nbmayjun05p94.html | title=What is Gentle Discipline? | journal=La Leche League International | access-date=2015-01-29 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150213160149/http://www.llli.org/nb/nbmayjun05p94.html | archive-date=2015-02-13 | dead-url=yes | df= }}; {{cite web | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/rhiana-maidenberg/attachment-parenting-plea_b_1339650.html | title=Attachment Parenting, Please Don't Take Away My Time-Outs! | access-date=2015-01-29 }} {{cite book |last=Frissell-Deppe |first=Tammy |title=Every Parent's Guide to Attachment Parenting: Getting back to basic instincts! |location=Dracut, MA |publisher=J.E.D. Publishing |year=1998 |isbn=0-9666341-4-4 |pages=127ff }}</ref> "positive discipline",<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.attachmentparenting.org/principles/discipline |title=Practice Positive Discipline |access-date=2015-01-29}}</ref> non-confrontative parenting * [[naturopathy]], [[holistic health]], [[homeopathy]], and decline of [[vaccination]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Granju |first1=Katie Allison |last2=Kennedy |first2=Betsy |title=Attachment Parenting: Instinctive Care for Your Baby and Young Child |location=New York, NY |publisher=Pocket Books |year=1999 |isbn=0-671-02762-X |pages=56 }}; {{cite web | url=http://www.healingourchildren.net/ |title=You Deserve a Vibrantly Healthy Child! |access-date=2015-01-24}}; {{cite web | url=http://babyreference.com/san-diego-resource-pages/ap-play-groups/ |title=Attachment Parenting Play Groups |access-date=2015-11-27}}</ref> William Sears' son Robert Sears published a ''Vaccine Book'' in 2007 which fueled the vaccine skepticism among parents,<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=Robert |title= The Vaccine Book: Making the Right Decision for Your Child |year=2007 |isbn= 978-0-316-01750-3 }} {{cite web | url=http://www.askdrsears.com/topics/health-concerns/vaccines |title=Vaccines |access-date=2015-01-14}}</ref> and in AP groups, parents are explicitly asked not to have their children vaccinated.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://shotofprevention.com/2011/05/24/when-did-attachment-parenting-come-to-mean-vaccine-refusal/ |title=When Did "Attachment Parenting" Come to Mean Vaccine Refusal? |access-date=2015-01-14}}</ref>
Some practices and preferences of AP parents are prevalent only in North America: * decline of infant [[circumcision]];<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |pages=59f}}; {{cite book |last=Frissell-Deppe |first=Tammy |title=Every Parent's Guide to Attachment Parenting: Getting back to basic instincts! |location=Dracut, MA |publisher=J.E.D. Publishing |year=1998 |isbn=0-9666341-4-4 |pages=143ff }}; {{cite book |last1=Granju |first1=Katie Allison |last2=Kennedy |first2=Betsy |title=Attachment Parenting: Instinctive Care for Your Baby and Young Child |location=New York, NY |publisher=Pocket Books |year=1999 |isbn=0-671-02762-X |pages=75ff }}</ref> in Europe, infant circumcision is relatively rare. * [[naturism]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://triadmomsonmain.com/my-blog/attachment_vs_detachment_parenting_which_one_is_for_you |title=Attachment Vs. Detachment Parenting: Which One Is For You? |access-date=2015-01-24}}</ref> * [[homeschooling]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.boba.com/blog/homeschooling-a-natural-progression-from-attachment-parenting |title=Homeschooling: A Natural Progression from Attachment Parenting |access-date=2015-01-24}}</ref> or [[unschooling]];<ref>{{cite web | url=http://sandradodd.com/attachment |title=Attachment Parenting Extended |access-date=2015-01-24}}; {{cite book |last=Dodd |first=Sandra |title=Big Book of Unschooling |edition=3. |year=2009 |isbn=978-0-557-18155-1 |pages=57 }}</ref> in Europe, homeschooling is less popular.
The Sears encourage some of these practices explicitly, for example non-smoking, healthy and home-prepared food, no circumcision, but don't comment on how they are supposed to be linked to the core ideas of attachment parenting.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5 |pages=15, 105 }} {{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |pages=59f, 137–140, 219}}</ref> Only in the case of positive discipline, the link is quite obvious.<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |pages=243f}}</ref>
=== Feminist perspective === In his ''Complete Book of Christian Parenting and Child Care'' (1997), William Sears opposes maternal occupation, because he is convinced that it harms the child:<ref name="pickert" />
{{Quotation | [Some] mothers choose to go back to their jobs quickly simply because they don't understand how disruptive that is to the well-being of their babies. So many babies in our culture are not being cared for in the way God designed, and we as a nation are paying the price.|William Sears|The Complete Book of Christian Parenting and Child Care (1997)}}
{{Quotation|Baby books (including my own) and child care experts extol the virtues of motherhood as the supreme career.|William Sears<ref>{{cite book |last=Sears |first=William |title=Creative Parenting: How to use the new continuum concept to raise children successfully from birth to adolescence |publisher=Dodd, Mead & Company |location=New York |year=1983 |orig-year=1982 |isbn=0-396-08264-5 |pages=185}}</ref>}}
Any form of intensive, obsessive mothering has, as Katha Pollitt stated, devastating consequences for the equality of treatment of women in the society.<ref name="pollitt" /> In France, [[Élisabeth Badinter]] argued that over-parenting, obsession with washable diapers and organic, home made infant food, and parenting practices as the ones recommended by Sears, with breastfeeding into toddlerhood, bring women inevitably back into outdated patterns of gender role. In the United States, Badinter's book ''The Conflict: How Modern Motherhood Undermines the Status of Women'' (2010) had a partially critical reception, because there is no publicly paid childcare leave in this country, and many women consider it a luxury to be able to be a stay-at-home-mom during the child's first years.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2012/04/23/elisabeth-badinter-s-the-conflict-does-modern-motherhood-undermine-women.html |title=Elisabeth Badinter’s ‘The Conflict’: Does Modern Motherhood Undermine Women? |newspaper=The Daily Beast|date=2012-04-23 |access-date=2015-01-20}} {{cite news | url=http://parenting.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/04/13/has-motherhood-replaced-sexism/?_r=0 |title=K. J. Dell’Antonia: ''Has Motherhood Replaced Sexism?'' |newspaper=The New York Times|date=2012-04-13 |access-date=2015-01-20 }}</ref> Still, gynecologist Amy Tuteur (formerly [[Harvard Medical School]]) stated that attachment parenting amounts to a new subjection of the woman's body under social control – a trend that is more than questionable in the face to the hard-fought achievements of women's movement.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.skepticalob.com/2013/03/natural-childbirth-attachment-parenting-and-policing-womens-bodies.html |last=Tuteur |first= Amy|title= Natural childbirth, attachment parenting, and policing women’s bodies |access-date=2015-01-27}}</ref>
As [[Erica Jong]] observed, the rise of attachment parenting followed a surge of glamourized motherhood of popular stars ([[Angelina Jolie]], [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], [[Gisele Bündchen]]) in the [[mass media]]. She stated that the effort to model exceptional children under sacrifice of the parent's own well-being transformed motherhood into a "highly competitive race"; all attempts of women to radically monopolize their parental responsibilities very much accommodate [[right-wing politics]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Jong |first=Erica | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704462704575590603553674296 |title=Mother Madness |access-date=2015-11-02 |newspaper=The Wall Street Journal |date=2010-11-06}}</ref>
=== A "culture of total motherhood" === In her 2005 book ''Perfect Madness. Motherhood in the Age of Anxiety'', [[Judith Warner]], too, described how attachment parenting has taken a strong influence on mainstream parenting and how it has established a "culture of total motherhood"; due to these cultural changes, mothers are convinced today that they have to instantly attend to every need of their children in order to protect them from the risk of livelong abandonment issues.<ref>{{cite book |last=Warner |first=Judith |title=Perfect Madness. Motherhood in the Age of Anxiety |publisher=Riverhead |year=2005 |isbn=1-59448-170-9}} {{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A33490-2005Feb17.html |last=Wilkinson |first=Stephanie |title= The Mommy Mystique |newspaper=Washington Post |date=2005-02-20 |access-date=2015-01-25 }} {{cite web |url=http://judithwarneronline.com/ |title=Judith Warner's web site |access-date=2015-01-25}}</ref> As early as in 1996, sociologist Sharon Hays wrote about a newly formed "ideology of intensive mothering". Characteristic of this ideology is the tendency to impose parenting responsibility primarily on ''mothers'' and to favor a kind of parenting that is child-centered, expert-guided, emotionally absorbing, labour- and financially intensive. Hays saw the motives for the overloading of motherhood in the idealistic endeavor to cure an overly egoistical and competitive society through a counterbalancing principle of altruistic motherliness. But according to Hays, any kind of "intensive motherhood" that systematically privileges children's needs over mothers' needs happens without fail to the economical and personal disadvantage of mothers.<ref>{{cite book|last=Hays |first=Sharon|title=The Cultural Contradictions of Motherhood |publisher=Yale University Press |year=1998 |isbn=0-300-07652-5}} {{cite web | url=http://yalebooks.com/book/9780300076523/cultural-contradictions-motherhood |title=The Cultural Contradictions of Motherhood |access-date=2016-02-23}} {{cite web | url=https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/sharon-hays/the-cultural-contradictions-of-motherhood/ |title=The Cultural Contradictions of Motherhood |access-date=2015-01-25 }} {{cite web |last=Douglas |first=Susan |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1u2uEMwHTys |title=Understanding parenting culture (video)}}</ref>
In 2014, a team of researchers at the [[University of Mary Washington]] showed in a study that 23% of mothers who believe in ''intensive motherhood'' suffer from signs of [[Depression (mood)|depression]]; among average mothers, this applies only to 6.7%.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Rizzo |first1=Kathryn M. |last2=Schiffrin |first2=Holly H. |last3=Liss |first3=Miriam |title=Insight into the parenthood paradox: mental health outcomes of intensive mothering |journal=Journal of Child and Family Studies |volume=22 |issue=5 |year=July 2012 |pages=614–620 |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/alicegwalton/2012/07/06/the-better-mother-how-intense-parenting-leads-to-depression/ |access-date=2015-01-24 |doi=10.1007/s10826-012-9615-z}}</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}}
==References== *{{cite book |last1=Granju |first1=Katie Allison |last2=Kennedy |first2=Betsy |title=Attachment Parenting: Instinctive Care for Your Baby and Young Child |location=New York, NY |publisher=Pocket Books |year=1999 |isbn=0-671-02762-X }} *{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=William |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The baby book : everything you need to know about your baby : from birth to age two |location=Boston |publisher=Little, Brown |year=1993 }} *{{cite book |last1=Sears |first1=Bill |last2=Sears |first2=Martha |title=The Attachment Parenting Book: A Commonsense Guide to Understanding and Nurturing Your Baby |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=New York, Boston |year=2001 |isbn=0-316-77809-5}}
==Further reading== <!-- Add a new title only if it is not in the footnotes yet, and if it is specifically about attachment parenting --> *Sears, Martha; Sears, William (1997). ''Complete Book of Christian Parenting and Child Care: A Medical and Moral Guide to Raising Happy Healthy Children'' *[http://psycnet.apa.org/fulltext/2014-55579-001.pdf ''The Benefits of Attachment Parenting for Infants and Children: A Behavioral Developmental View'']
